title: How does one become a hacker? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sounds pretty much like Baker.. Quite different.. it's "HACKER" The coolest way to be a hacker:1.) Buy a long, black trench coat.  2.) Get a skateboard. Preferably a large-tail one like Bart Simpson rides circa early '90s. 3.) Have a large disposable supply of Macbooks Pros, cleverly built in translucent polycarbonate containers. 4.) Transmit everything physically over 3.4 inch floppies (PRISM, obviously).  5.) Get a super legit handle like "Z3r0C001" or "ThePlague." Everyone on /r/h4x0r will hate you if you have something frowntown like - you know - your name. 6.) Get a job at a large Fortune500 company as their head of security with absolutely no credentials, proof of expertise, or reason why you should be there. Given that it's also implicitly implied that you have a significant criminal background, do something magical to ensure that it doesn't come out in your background check. 7.) Stalk the streets of New York like you're fucking Spiderman and come out of the cuts to get sensitive information on floppy by holding onto the side door of your probably very confused Uber driver (note: you will probably not get a 5 star customer rating for this).  The less cool but actually-relevant way to get into information security:1.) Get really excited about programming. Anyone that tells you that you don't need to program (or at least have a strong background in programming) to be a security engineer either is lying to you or doesn't want you to get past the entry level. Being able to smash the stack is one thing. Understanding that you can't smash the stack in a given interpreted language because the interpreter won't let you is another. Knowing that a certain bug reported recently in the intrepreter's garbage collector could be exploited to effectively the same thing is the kind of stuff that gets you acclaim and promotions is the consequence of spending alot of time programming.  2.) Study computer science and mathematics. A good CS degree will get you some of the way there with regards to tech skills (*nix, some networking if you choose to do so, etc.) If you really want to get into security, getting into cryptography while you're in college is a must and will give you deep insight into the architecture of encryption.    A strong foundation in theory and computer science is a clutch skill for any security professional. The day Knuth decides to become a criminal hacker is the day we're all screwed. 3.) Get internships that will teach you how software engineering and programming actually works in the real world. Try to get a diverse range of companies here: startups, F500s, etc. 4.) After you intern and get exposed to the real world, try to get a feel for where you want to start your adventure. Do you want to be on the front lines as a sysadmin? Do you want to be a software engineer building security products? Do you want to be a security architect or manager? 5.) Given your choice in 4, research what you need to get an entry level position in that field. In some cases you may need to get certifications like CISSP. If you want to go government, note that you'll probably also have to get clearance. If that's the case, get ready to deal with the polygraph and stop doing illegal shit like smoking weed (this is a huge deal-breaker for most folks going for TS+) immediately.  6.) Get to know the scene. Hang out at 2600 meetings. Go to DefCon and Blackcon. Make friends. Learn a ton. Discover how blatantly wrong the media is about people who live and work in information security.   7.) Learn to be social and communicate with others regardless of their technical background. This is essential in any field of tech, and will give you flexibility to basically go anywhere and do anything.  Most important of all: Enjoy it. This is a field that requires a lot of passion to stay current in. It's also a field where things aren't usually filled with riveting excitement. When things are that exciting, it's usually because something horrible happened.  If you don't like security but you want to be come a "1337 h4x0r" because of great romantic comedies like Hackers, you're destined for failure. But if you're passionate about infosec, technology, and are willing to put in the wrench time you can absolutely make a difference in this field of high tech. So, it's all about your passion and dedication towards "Hacking" patience being one of the most important one..All the Best !!

Here's is my personal "how."  Perhaps it will be enlightening to you.  6th grade:  I was there in the hallway, alone.  Can't remember how or why, but I was just there, idle, bored.   I see the locked doors to the classrooms and approach. Young eyes  contemplate the lock and imagine possibilities...  are there any? It's locked right?  Should not do anything.  People expect it to do nothing and ignore it, unless they have the key, but is that really true? And the hack begins. I felt the locked knob, pushed it in, pulled it out, wiggled it, and settled in on jiggling it back and forth varying speed, pressure, timing, etc...  At first, it was just all about what movement can actually happen in the locked state. Then it was about exploring the boundaries of that movement. And during that exploration, more movement was possible!  And more, and more, and it opened and I was in!  No key.   I arrived at a place where I could open most doors in that building by simply standing there and manipulating the knob!  Took maybe a minute on average, sometimes far less. No joke. Turns out, that style of lock wasn't the very best, and it's manufacturing tolerances were not sufficient to prevent opening under all conditions, or maybe better said, enough conditions to prevent manipulation as a means to get past the locking structures. At that time, I knew little about locks, but I did have a sense of the world and was always exploring the dynamics of everyday things.   For me, I sometimes frame this as, "unexpected input" and I'll provide it just to see if the rules are the rules in the world, or if everything is planned for, or engineered to perform exactly to spec. Often it isn't.  More interestingly, and possibly disturbingly at times, it's more often than your average person would think. Where there are gaps in our understanding, or rules, or the dynamics of  devices, people and things, there exists the potential for the hack, or that providing of input that maybe isn't typical, or expected, or planned for, or reasonable. Another one was the phone.  We had an old dial phone when I was growing up.  I was messing with it one day and got a connect by repeatedly clicking the "hang up" switch.  Turns out, that's how a dial phone works!  I had got the operator after a sequence of 10 clicks that fell within the timing constraints the system needed to recognize that activity as a dial as opposed to somebody just manipulating the phone, like to move the handset and straighten out the cord. Once I was aware of that, of course, what else can it do? And there is the hacking exposed.  I quickly learned to dial calls without the dial. So I dialed up a friend, and we toyed with the phones while on a call.  At  some point, we ended up in a three way call with an operator, who was very confused. Worse, none of us could end the call!  Even when all three of us hung up and waited, the call was connected!  A tech had to fix it, and I got a lecture about the phones. A few years later, I got a field trip at school and it was to the phone company.   They showed us the mechanical system that would connect calls!  It was this impressive thing with levers, terminals, connectors, etc... and  when people dialed up, it would position things so that the phones were  connected and then the call could happen. Nobody ever checked it thoroughly for the "receiving pulses while already on a call" case, and we had triggered the system to make a type of connection it was not designed for.  And it worked just fine otherwise, because the vast majority of people would provide expected and planned for inputs. For all I know, my friend and I were the first to expose that functionality in the system.  "call locking"  heh So there are a couple examples. I must say something else here too. There is benign hacking.  One learns about the world by providing inputs to it, or doing stuff.  Learn by doing, and or playing. And that little kid spark, that sense of "play" stays with people who are  inclined to hack.  It never, ever goes away.  It's in me, and even though I've been here a while, I still will encounter something novel to me, and that kicks in.  "let's play with it!"   What does it do?  What is is supposed to do? Those are two entirely different questions! IMHO,  this kind of hacking is an ordinary human thing.  Curious humans will attempt to learn by doing.  And in a way, it's a little like the scientific method applied in life.  One wonders, makes a guess and tries things to see if the result can be reproduced or predicted.  That's basically science to gain understanding. Or, one does stuff to watch and learn.  Less scientific, but often revealing.  Maybe something is discovered in this play, and that leads to deep and potent understanding. It's intrinsic to me.  Always has been.  Standard feature.  I have to pay attention to not do it in some contexts.   Where a person goes with all of that that could end up nefarious too.   With understanding comes responsibility.  I never pay for locksmiths, for example.  Nor does anyone who knows me.   But you also will never find me on the wrong side of the intent of a lock either, not without cause. Damn good cause. And I think this makes some people uneasy.  It's on the honor system mostly.   Of course, we can and do catch people on the poor side of honor and there is a process for all of that as our awesome friend Adrián Lamo has shared with us, for example.  (Adrian knows I wrote this and why and that it's with the best of intent.  He suggested this be an answer and so it is.) And you know what?  He's still on the honor system, and is demonstrating  honor in his frank and very entertaining sharing of his experiences.  I think very highly of that and anytime we can share "the hack" or the nature of it, good things happen way more than bad things do.   So I'm a fan, and I worry sometimes over our reaction and the sometimes painful pressure to suppress that spark in people.  Sometimes it goes in ways we would rather not have had it go, but man!  Most of the time it's just empowering and good things happen. I'm about the good things.  The more the merrier.   And I worry that they, and I mean society overall, fails to see the  empowerment as the net gain it is.  Sometimes I worry a lot.  I've been  shunned in my life for people just knowing I had that inclination.   It's that inclination to hack and understand that nets us so much!  And for  me, growing up in poverty, it was the difference between a depressing,  crappy life, and an awesome one learning all sorts of stuff! When things are good, hacks can seem frivolous.  And maybe they are,  entertainment and enlightenment aside.  One can say the same of a trickster or clown too.  The trickster is a sort of hacker in how they come to toy with people to gain understanding of their perceptions. Ask Penn and Teller, one of whom is published scientifically and peer  reviewed [1] on the topic of human perception.  There is value in all of  that, and for them, money.  Plenty of it.   [1] turning tricks into research : Article : Nature Reviews Neuroscience But, when things are bad? This is when you want to know somebody inclined to hacking, or develop it in your own self. As a little kid, I remember the day I realized there are the official possible things to do.  And that's often a subset of human extreme limits.   And that set of things is a subset of the actual possibilities our world will permit.   Physics, basically.  Every last one of the great physicists are hackers.  They  want to pry reality open and look at the pieces inside to understand. Think of how all of it can work like a safety factor.  Most people stay in the safety factor and they may not understand there is some safety built in too.  Some do have that understanding and will operate outside that safety factor, but still within their own personal limits as a human. And then there comes a time and place where one must do what it takes.   Sometimes limits aren't there, but for our own understanding!   Realizing this changes a person just a little.  And it can happen in all kinds of ways.   Many, who are inclined to hacking of various kinds, understand "do what it  takes" in a more absolute sense than we may find a more typical person  does. Finally, a girl I knew growing up wanted to hack.  She could see it and would play with me regularly.  And by play, I mean with tech, the world, people, etc...  One day I picked up a pen and asked her what she saw.  "A pen, of course silly!" I told her I saw a device, and it has parts, and they have properties, and all of that is setup to perform the task of writing, but one does not technically have to write with the pen. "But how do you know?" "Take it apart.  See?  Look at all this stuff!" ... and so the conversation went. Most of the time, a pen is just a pen.  When one needs or is bored, a pen is a resource, or tool, or toy, weapon, etc... And she and I spent many hours taking stuff apart or doing novel things.   I think the hacker "spark" can be shared.  It's latent in many people.   And in a way, I think it's a lot like inhibition in general.  One can crack that by having experiences.  This is part of why we make people speak in public as kids a time or two.  We want to stimulate them to see what comes of it. Most people experience an ordinary outcome:  "OK, I can do this."  But some people find out they love it, or are great somehow!  We lose out, if we don't give everybody a go.   The hacker simply does that same kind of thing with the world they live in and the people and or stuff they find in it. Hope that helps convey what "hacking" actually is.   Really, "hacking" has nothing at all to do with computers and networks.  Those things are just very compelling targets for hacking, and because of  that, there is a lot of hacking going on. But the nature of the hacker is distinct apart from all of that.  Anything that can do something, or that has complex dynamics, or functions, can be hacked on and the products of that hack are understanding of that thing that goes deeper than the obvious, or official, or expected types of understanding.

Ahhh, so you want to enter into the wonderful world of pen testing. Note, I said pen testing and not “hacking”. One reason I did this is because I believe that simply breaking into something you don’t own is a recipe for a dead end job. It’s like saying “I want to learn to lock pick so I can go steal a bunch of stuff out of peoples houses”. Eventually you will get caught. On the other hand, you could have someone pay you much more to test the security of their business. But once you get a record, very few places will hire you. A record is not “street cred” and doesn’t represent someone who is better at the craft. It’s a liability. On to the meat of the subject. To enter the world of being a pen tester, there is some foundational knowledge required like networking, linux, window administration, and optionally learn how to code (IMHO coding helps with the journey as it forces an understanding of computer architecture). Next pick up a copy of Penetration Testing by Georgia Weidman. It’s a bit dated but the content is still very relevant. That’ll take you through a lot of the fundamentals around using kali linux, getting your lab set up, etc. After tearing through the book, you have enough knowledge to be dangerous and more than enough to get 5–7 in federal. Pull down a bunch of images on vulnhub and go to town. Keep your lab network isolated. Some of these VMs are the equivalent of setting a dumpster fire inside your house. After that, if you are not burnt out, go through the OSCP certification. Plan on spending at least 3 months in the labs and realize there will not be a whole lot of hand holding. It’s designed to be frustrating. At the end of the day, pen testing is about being persistent, having a curious mind, an understanding of the underlying technology, with some social engineering mixed in. There are of course, more facets than just that but being a pen tester really represents a neat intersection of psychology and engineering. Another part of that is often not mentioned is to network, network, network. Start attending OWASP meetups. You may find that the breaker track (AKA Pen Tester) is not what you want to do. The builder and defender side is also a lot of fun. Personally I tend to hang out on the builder side of the spectrum. To repeat my earlier caveat, and what I tell everyone that I demonstrate a bit of the “dark arts” to, if you don’t own it, don’t break into it. There is no such thing as a “grey hat”. You are a black hat if you break into something you don’t own and do not have permission to break into. If someone does give you permission to break into their stuff, make sure you have a written contract saying it’s ok (AKA get out of jail free card). Eventually you will get to know law enforcement in this field, you want to know them as peers and not as someone who is stuffing you into the back of a cruiser :) Good luck!

“Hacker”: a person who uses computers to gain unauthorized access to data. You want to learn how to be a hacker? Start off by doing the following. * NEVER ask anyone how to be a hacker. That just shows that you are not ready for this and probably won’t make it very far. If you REALLY want to learn, then you need to dedicate yourself towards it and set goals for what you want to learn. Start by doing, not by asking. You’ll learn more and more on the way and eventually, you’ll be the one who’s writing answers to questions like these. If you really want to become a “hacker”, you’ll need to specify what type you want to be. White hat? Black hat? Grey hat? Here are some definitions. Grey Hat: The term "grey hat" refers to a computer hacker or computer security expert who may sometimes violate laws or typical ethical standards, but does not have the malicious intent typical of a black hat hacker. White Hat: A white hat hacker is a computer security specialist who breaks into protected systems and networks to test and asses their security. White hat hackers use their skills to improve security by exposing vulnerabilities before malicious hackers (known as black hat hackers) can detect and exploit them. And a black hat hacker is one that maliciously perpetrates and exploits Let’s say you wanted to learn how to break into websites. The first thing you would need to do is figure out how websites work. Start by teaching yourself some mark up & programming languages. I’d recommend starting in the following order:* HTML* CSS* PHP* JavaScript *Python * #C* VB.NET* Ruby * Perl Python would be one of the best languages to learn for scripting, automating things and learning to use exploits by coding them. The rest are just good to know and will help you be better at this, instead of being a script kiddy who uses tools found online for everything. I guess you’d also have to learn a language like SQL, as SQL injection is one of the main forms of attacking a website. Look into reading about the exploits available online, here are a few to start you off. (Go read the OWASP TOP 10) * SQL Injection * XSS (Cross site scripting)* LFI (Local file inclusion)Figuring out how to use an API to exploit a website is one of the more intermediate steps. Depending on the website, sometimes they’ll have a lot of exploits available within their API. Find these and report them if you want. Don’t be a blackhat and abuse them as that won’t get you far. For example, there was one in Uber a short while ago that allowed you to change the password of any other user using their API. rt/passwordless-signup or something like that. Start simple. Codeacademy.com, w3schools, ect.

If I understand your question, you want to know about to find security related issues in any system(may be software, networks, servers or anything else) and then exploit the system. First realise that there is no any software that can fully automate the whole process. There are bunch of Linux distros(Like Backtrack, Kali Linux, BlackBuntu, Blackbox, etc) that can help you to make things easier, but if you want to really learn the things I would recommend you to install a basic OS like Ubuntu and install all the software by your own. Here are some rules to follow if you really want to learn hacking:1. Never GiveUp(Because no software ever made which don't have any bugs, if software is good then there may be some platform vulnerability)2. There is no any software that can fully automate the process of hacking anything, So first you will have to learn and the execute.3. Follow OpenSource as much as possible, because buying all software cause you lot of money and cracks will first spy on you.4. Never try to run any program blindly in your main machine, First try to find if the software is from trusted source then it OK but if is not then install it in Virtual machine.5. Learn to test not to exploit, if you found anything report it to developers.6. Avoid fishing and keylogging because they are not hacking they are a chip form of cheating. Hacking is the process you can start anywhere, first you have to know about what defect any system poses and then you can exploit as you want. If you want to follow some formal stepsStep 1: Install Ubuntu and some most basic tools you can start with. I would recommend the following: (i) Armitage with Metasploit{Penetration Testing Software, Pen Testing Security | Metasploit}: Metasploit contains thousands of exploits for almost all types of systems. You can use those exploits to execute on the system you want. You can find bunch of resources on youtube, Official website and (Page on securitytube.net) Security tube. Apart from this you can search on google blogs for more diverse list.(ii) Nmap{Free Security Scanner For Network Exploration & Security Audits.}: Best tool for scanning Networks or servers.You can search on youtube and google blogs for resources. (iii) Wireshark{Wireshark · Go Deep.}: Best tool for analysing data packets in the same networks. Security-Tube(Page on securitytube.net) Has a whole mega-primer on WLAN security and network related issues, I think this video lacture is enough for anyone to learn about wireshark, WLAN Security, etc.(iv) SET(Social Engineering toolkit){trustedsec/social-engineer-toolkit}: Best social engineering toolkit which uses Vulnerabilities in windows softwares to perform Man-in-the-middle attack on the system. (v) Air-crack{Aircrack-ng}: For wi-fi and related things.(vi) TCPDump{TCPDUMP/LIBPCAP public repository}: Very good command line data packet analyser. (vii) Nikto{Nikto2 | CIRT.net}: Web server scanner. (viii) THC Hydra: Good for brute force type attacks. Apart from this you can find very good list at VulnerabilityAssessment.co.uk. You can also install Kali linux, Backtrack, BlackBuntu or Blackbox all of them contains the tools given above.Step 2: Dig deep and gather as much as information you can. This will help you to understand better about the system and the defects present in the system.Step 3: Always try to have latest tools and latest global vulnerabilities exposed in the systems.Step 4: Try every possible attack on system you want to hack. Some of the most recommended websites:1. VulnerabilityAssessment.co.uk2. The Hacker News — Hacking, Cyber and Internet Security3. Exploits Database by Offensive Security4. CERN Computer Security information5. Page on owasp.org6. Welcome to SecurityTube.net P.S.: Please do all the things for learning and testing purpose and in virtual machine as much as possible because some scripts may cause very harm for your computer.108.1k Views · View UpvotersUpvote · 357 Comment...RecommendedAllPromoted by Blinkist A smarter you is only 15 minutes away. Try the Blinkist app.Read or listen to the world's best nonfiction books in a matter of minutes and become a smarter you.Get the App Saifur Rahman Mohsin, Loves to write good code :)Updated Jan 24Originally Answered: How do I get started Ethical Hacking from scratch? What should I do first?First, you need to decide what kind of a hacker you want to be. Depending on your area of interest there are several choices you could make.. You may be one who specialises inWeb Application HackingDesktop Application HackingHardware HackingMobile Application HackingAnd these are just some common options, and it's really a much larger set of options than these few...The term hacking is a much larger word that describes a person who does something so brilliantly that he gets that thing done much faster than what others would take. In the context of this question, however, you probably meant a computer hacker who does it with certain ethics.Assuming that you want to be a web hacker(those are the ones that are popular today--Julian Assange, Mark Zuckerberg, Kevin Mitnick, etc.) this is my idea of probably the best pathway..Learn the basic languages that make the web--this ranges from the plain 'ol HTML that gives structure to pages, to CSS that causes styles and JS that gives logic to the pages. Once your armed with the knowledge of these, you move to server side scripting languages like PHP, Node.JS, etc. and start build web applications of your own. It would be a good idea to extend over these as well.. For exampleHTML --> HTML5, etc.CSS --> LESS, SASS, etc.JS --> JQuery, AngularJS, etc.You would begin to understand how most web apps today (like Facebook, Twitter or even Quora) work and how you can exploit the vulnerabilities that are not taken care of properly. You will be forced to learn a bit of Unix as the most web servers that run web apps will run this OS. You then learn to use tools that automate manual testing and make it easier to identify problems -- tools like SQLNinja, Havij, Nessus etc. to automate SQL injection, XSS and other tests. for pen testing frameworks like metasploit, w3af, etc. which would give you a greater control to perform tests, deploy malware payloads and even write your own exploits. This way you eventually learn about cross-side scripting, javascript exploits, how cookies works, how browsers work, how to write good web apps, how to identify bad web apps and so on..You would eventually learn loads of new attack vectors everyday and get into the loop. You will start finding holes in web apps that already exist and report it to them to get money from their bounty programs that they offer or if you turn black hat you would probably sell those exploits as zero days in the dark web for bigger cash to other malware writers (but this is out of context as it isn't ethical hacking).I'd like to share even the desktop application pathway i.e. to become desktop app hacker, just incase you had expected that. Mobile app pathway is an extension over this so you can go there after following this pathway. It basically the same, except for a more specific set of languages and using more specific set of tools.You'd have to start out by learning how computers work. Learn the basic language like C and maybe even low level languages. I have recommended a good book (See reference #1 at end of the post) for taking up this pathway. That will not only teach you the working of computers but also how to write low level codes like assembly codes or shell codes, etc. You can take up malware writing as a pathway and transgress the ethics to become a full time malware writer but then if you want to stick with desktop hacking then you'd have to learn how debuggers work and how you can re-assemble, reverse engineered binaries and see where it cracks. Here too, you can go astray and become a full time reverse engineer who cracks softwares/games and programs to put them in p2p networks or sell it in the dark web (this is a good business these days and chances of getting hired or jailed by corporates are also high). Or, you could stick to the original pathway and build robust desktop apps and learn how to hack these apps. Make obfuscated code to protect these apps and learn to develop obfuscation tools and other useful tools that may help you hack away.! You can design key loggers, RAT (remote administration tools), TSRs and even crypters. These are of high value in the market as well as useful for your own needs. Companies look out for security experts to make audits and assessments of their own products and services and it's good money for less work. You'll basically be using pre-existing tools to make these assessments and pinning developers for the flaws in the code.Either pathway you choose, at that one point you are likely to understand that you've learnt a lot, more than just hacking. You would realise that the whole process was for you to become a better person. That's what I've learnt so far--that as a hacker you are inclined to push yourself to see it things can be done differently. It may sound silly that I tell you now but this is the crux of hacking--that we make our own life better as well as others lives by introducing tricks to do things more efficiently. So there you go.. that's my two cents for those wish to travel this less travelled path. And remember, this isn't easy because the only hackers that we know are the greatest hackers alive--Julian Assange, Steve Wozniak, etc. It's a field with high demand and competition and everybody wants to do it. Only few end up in the books, some end up in jail and some in both. Hope you make the right choices!Tips1. Follow videos on youtube like Defcon, Notacon, Blackhat, etc. (read reference #4 for more on this)2. Read news about new exploits or security holes or even patches made to existing apps so that you can attack those who do not update to those patches (if your a BlackHat). This is quite popular among hackers--Microsoft came up with a term Patch Tuesday to release security updates. Among hackers, we call the very next day as Exploit Wednesday as hackers can just RE those patches and see how to attack those users that have not applied these patches.3. Google! There are other search engines as well (true). Learn to use google well -- google about google dorking and learn how you can effectively use it to get the best results of what your looking for.4. Use your intelligence and common sense. This applies to everything you do. Lets take the scenario of tip #3. Common sense dictates that to find the latest hacks and patches you'd have to use the search tools in google to find the recently updated news (past week, past hour, etc.). If you're a decent hacker at that time, you'd probably make an app to automatically drag these as updates and post it to you as SMS texts, RSS entries or some sort of desktop / mobile alerts!5. Complete one pathway till you're satisfied. Do not decide you want to be a master of all hacking pathways and end up going absolutely nowhere. You want to be the jack of all trades and master of some.6. Tip #5 applies to languages as well (and in extension, to almost any task you do in life). If you start with say; PHP; then stick with it until your recognised as a good PHP developer or until your satisfied by making several apps before your shift to another language.7. Don't ever give up. Focus is everything. This may sound very absurd as a tip but truth is that many hackers give up because "the grapes are sour". I've noticed so many who say stuff like "Facebook is unhackable", etc. but believe me--it is. They have a nice whitehat program and you can read about past hacks (search for the hall of fame entries and their works) to get an idea, and you too will be able to come up with exploits once you get in the loop. But by then, hopefully you'd learn not to use the knowledge for all the wrong reasons! So always stay focussed!!References1. The Art of Exploitation by Jon Erickson (This defines programming and teaches hacking in a good view point).2. Network Security by Jan Harrington (To learn the basics of networking).3. Head First Series (Select the language you want to learn and use these books to learn the basics, you can use the online reference or documentation to learn the language further).4. Youtube videos--use VDO Downloader or youtube-dl to download entire playlists related to any topic your looking for and watch it! Youtube does have advanced search to selectively search channels/playlists.By the time you finish these books you'd have learned quite a lot and realize that hacking is actually changing the question "How do I get started Ethical Hacking from scratch? What should I do first?" to "Hey check out this cool attack vector that I just discovered". Now that's truly the essence of hacking.!Happy Hacking!

A good question to ask, since most people think you can just jump straight into hacking with no knowledge whatsoever. Like ‘life’, hacking is not that simple either - anybody that says differently does not know what is involved. Hardware or Software?Initially, you need to know the difference between hardware and software, some would say that’s simple, but break it down further to component level or interface type and you soon see many people with blank faces. Equipment IDA good understanding of hardware is essential, not just with computers but many I/O devices, routers, switches, operating speeds of various interfaces (are they backward compatible? etc). Electronics is a bonus!The ability of the understanding of electronics to component level and know how to read their values is also a step in the right direction. I had a good knowledge of electronics and electricity when I was only 12 years old, back when I was developing prototype projects for people (custom projects). Programming in the 80’sIn the early 80’s I started working with computers, nothing like today’s standards, but we even hacked back then, mostly pranks or phreaking techniques. Public phones were everywhere back then, and using a special black box we used to build we could make free calls to anywhere in the world - now that sounds easy, I can assure you unless you knew telephony exchanges functioned you would have no idea how we did such things. Hacking is just one of activities you can do with computers and devices. You don’t break these machines (to break means crashing the machine, render it unusable or useless) but rather, make them do things that are not expected by humans. It is simply beating the opposing force (human or machine) using the rules that machines understand. The rules are basically streams of ones and zeroes from the viewpoint of these machines. To understand the machine, you have to know at least the following topics: Number systems - conversions and implementations (binary, hexadecimal, and octal). You don’t have to be good at this one, just a basic know-how since we can always use calculators to do the work for us.Computer Architecture and Organization. Understand various computer models and their implementations. Understand CPU internals, how memory and its hierarchy, buses, and I/O subsystems work together. Understand what a program is and how it is processed by the machine. Understand why programs that work in one system don’t work in another (e.g., why Windows executables don’t run in a Linux environment without special help). Understand that everything we know about the machine are mere abstractions because machines only understand ones and zeroes (digital signals).Operating Systems (OS). Understand the purpose of this software and its internals. Understand how processes and threads work. How it loads programs and make them run. Understand how it protects itself and the resources it must protect. Understand the various OS limitations, weaknesses, design, and their complexity. Understand how it implements networking. Learn how it can hide itself, its services, and applications from other devices.Programming. Understand at least two programming languages, their features, the build process, the tools or technologies you need to use at each stage or phase, the various methodologies available (there’s more than one way to build software) and the IT roles associated with them. Understand how a program is made and how it transforms into something that is valid and acceptable to the OS. Understand various programming models and their implementations. Understand how to debug and reverse engineer your own code.Networking. Understand various network communication models and their implementations. Understand TCP/IP suite(the whole stack) and its alternatives. Understand different network devices that work at different layers. Understand IP addressing and how devices use them. Understand Ethernet and its wireless version. Understand how TCP/IP is implemented by different OS. Understand your LAN adapter. Understand how network devices work and how they can be protected. Know their limitations and weaknesses. Understand HTTP and HTTPS, POP3, IMAP, SMTP, and File Transfer protocols because they’re staple in most organization.Databases. Understand various database models and their implementations. Understand RDBMS and SQL Standards. Understand NoSQL. Understand how databases are designed and implemented, how they are used and how they can be protected and abused.Hardware. If you understand a lot of technical information on how computer hardware works, you are ahead of the pack.I think that’s the basics. Start from number one and then finish number six. If you have these basic skills then you can basically do what you want. You will realize later that you cannot learn everything. You’ll have to specialize. You must also understand that anything you do outside your home laboratory has legal, political, economic, and social consequences. Do not let curiosity rob you of your freedom. Your knowledge is useless in prison. Don’t be stupid. Learn everything in an isolated environment (home laboratory set up). Remember, do not think you are special or look down on others. You are not unique. There are millions of people in this world who can do what you do. Keep the know-how to yourself because nobody cares what you know. Use your abilities to help people, your company and/or your government.

so .. you want to be hacker??… A perfect hacker ! , but keep in mind nothing is perfect in the world…….. If you are reading this , you too probably aspire to become a hacker. That's good. let's take a moment to look at what makes a good hacker. The Route to Become a Hacker The route to becoming a hacker is not an easy one. Some newbies to this field think that all need is some magic "hacking tool" and you can simply hack into any computer. That's far from the truth. Unlike other IT professions, a great hacker needs to understand most of the information technology disciplines including networking, databases, operating systems, web serving, scripting, cryptography, etc. In addition, the hacker needs to have functional knowledge of multiple operating systems including Linux, Mac OS and Windows. This may take years of experience and/or study. Then, after learning how these various information technology systems WORK, you then need to focus on how to BREAK them. This may require additional training and experience. Think Outside the Box Hacking is NOT like other areas of IT. In most IT disciplines, you learn that if you do this... and then that... and then that, the system does what you want. That is NOT usually the case with hacking! Good hackers have to think outside the box or tablet.You have to think about how you can make a system work in ways it was NOT designed to work. We need to understand intimately how systems work, so that we can make them operate in ways that their developers never intended! Persistence It also important to note that not every hack works every time. Depending upon the circumstances, a hack might work now and then not work a short time later. We need to then figure what changed and then re-attempt the hack in a different way. In addition, a hack might work once and then never work again. For instance, if you are trying to remote code execution, this usually requires a buffer overflow. When the buffer is overflowed, it sometimes can become damaged and will not work properly again. In that case, you only get one shot to hack the system. Creative Hackers must be also be creative. SKILLS THAT YOU WILL NEED Programming: This is the most important. Learn how to solve problems and automate tasks.- Operating Systems: Learn not (only) how to use them, but how they work, how and where it stores (important) information, how to access it's APIs.- Networking: Know how networks works, not only the concepts, but the inner workings too, how each type of packet is formed and the tricks you can do manipulating its bits. And learn how to use this knowledge with some programming language.- Website Hacking: There are lots of techniques to do this, just google OWASP. This 4 are the main in my opinion, you can be an average to good hacker with this. To be a ninja you'll need more: - Cryptography: Deep knowledge, how to use, how to implement common cyphers and how to break them. (By common cyphers I mean cyphers used today, like RSA, not caesar's cypthers and others like this) . - Reverse Engineering (and debugging): How to debug or disassemble and analyse software to see what and how a software process its information and how to extract this information from memory at run time.- (Anti-) Forensics: Where incriminating information is stored and how to safely erase them.- Exploit writing: You need to know debugging and computer memory to do this. I think this is all. Sorry for english errors. i hope u got the all point …all the best

At it's core hacking is the ability to trick a system into doing something it wasn't intended to do. For Computers this almost always means getting the target computer to execute code or commands that it shouldn't. I'll assume that you already know some programming language.If not, start there. More than understanding the language, you need to understand how a computer understands a language.Is it compiled or interpreted? What are threads? What are interfaces? How does a program at run-time interact with other programs? (the OS, the web-server, browser with plugins...) How do programs on different systems interact? (web-server with browser, web-server with interpreter, interpreter web server with database...) Everything that runs on a computer relies on something else running first. The bios loads the OS, the OS loads and links the application or loads the interpreter. The interpreter loads the script...Everything that runs on the computer takes input and produces output (from/to users or other systems). Clients with servers, nodes with other nodes on a network, processes with other processes... Understanding how and why these things work will reveal avenues for tricking a computer into executing something it shouldn't. That is, getting the processor to execute a set of instructions that you provide. Once these concepts are firmly understood, you can start learning some of the exploits. I won't get into them here, but you can find readily discover some of the more common ones, and go to conferences to stay updated on the newly discovered ones.To learn them and truly understand them you have to practice them. Write a program that's vulnerable. Try your attack. Did it work? why? Now secure your program? Did your fix work? don't stop there. Can you get around the fix you just coded? Can you harden it further? Is your fix reusable in other applications? No? then how would you generalize your solution? Infosec is a mindset. In many ways it's like doing QA. You need to think about every possible way to misuse a system. Not just maliciously, but every possible input, platform, setting that the designer didn't think about taking into account when they designed the system. Then stop thinking about it and break someone's code.

I agree with Stan Hanks that hackers are born, not made. And they are popularly viewed as a kind of Prestige Class of geek, mysterious and exciting, and as such are the object of many a fantasy. But you can be perfectly good at security without being a "hacker".  (Note: It's typically not as exciting as portrayed in media, though it can have exciting moments. See my answer to "What is it like to be a hacker / member of a cybercrime organization?" for more info.)   It's good to feel wanted But the hallmark of a hacker is the intense passion about their area of interest that drives them to learn and excel. They don't ask people "teach me to [x]" because learning about [x] is so fascinating for them that they wouldn't want someone else to infringe on the fun. They might accept tips now and then, but not roadmaps.  If you want to hack, but you're not interested enough to make your own way, to learn and discover and spend the countless hours reading and exploring and experimenting without someone else to hold your hand, you're not a hacker. I'm sorry to be blunt about it, but it's better to just tell you that now.  You can still work in security. You can still be a penetration tester. Hell, other people may still consider you a hacker. Don't consider it a step down in life. Everyone learns differently. Not everyone gets to grow up to be an astronaut, and not everyone gets to be a hacker.  This discussion is as old as the 'net. Here's a rant that was published during my early learning days. Some of the references (Red box) are kind of dated, but the message holds true today:   Take a little quiz for me today. Tell me if you fit this description. You got your net account several months ago. You have been surfing the net, and you laugh at those media reports of the information superhighway. You have a red box, you don't have to pay for phone calls. You have crackerjack, and you have run it on the password file at a unix you got an account on. Everyone at your school is impressed by your computer knowledge, you are the one the teachers ask for help.  Does this sound like you? You are not a hacker. There are thousands of you out there. You buy 2600 and you ask questions. You read phrack and you ask questions. You join #hack and you ask questions. You ask all of these questions, and you ask what is wrong with that? After all, to be a hacker is to question things, is it not?  But, you do not want knowledge. You want answers. You do not want to learn how things work. You want answers. You do not want to explore. All you want to know is the answer to your damn questions.  You are not a hacker. Hacking is not about answers. Hacking is about the path you take to find the answers. If you want help, don't ask for answers, ask for a pointer to the path you need to take to find out those answers for yourself.  Because it is not the people with the answers that are the hackers, it is the people that are travelling along the path. via Are You A Hacker? by ReDragon - original via Internet Relay Chat  Related: Adrián Lamo's answer to How did Adrian Lamo learn hacking?Adrián Lamo's answer to Can you be a hacker if you can't code?Kevin Poulsen's answer to How does one become a hacker?Stan Hanks' answer to How does one become a hacker?

My general advice is based on my own journey out of college many years ago, but with how I’d go about it today: Start reading articles and papers on ethical hacking. If you’re ok at self-studying, free online courses might be your thing. Focus on one area that you feel most comfortable to learn: networks, operating systems, native apps, web apps, mobile devices/IoT… there’s a vast space out there, and you’ll get overwhelmed if you aren’t focused at first.Sidenote; Definitely spend time learning to code if you aren’t already studying this.Look for “hackme” and “crackme” communities. I’m not sure which are the best, but some searching around you can find sites like Hack This Site or Hack.me · The house of rising sandbox. These communities give you a safe/sanctioned way to practice. The key is you are either being given consent to practice on someone else’s infrastructure, or you host it privately (i.e. run services on a Raspberry Pi at home). These communities tend to have people like you (and more experienced folks) who can help point you in the right direction.Whatever you do, don’t practice on real world systems / computers. I’m not a lawyer, but accessing the systems of another company or entity without authorization will get you in a lot of trouble.Think of attending actual hacker conferences and get a feel for the overall scene. I “think” Defcon is still relevant these days, and is attended by professionals, academics and hobbyists alike.Once you build up your skills, start looking for companies that hire security professionals, or even the government. If you come to the table with the basics, you’re bound to find an internship / entry level position quickly.Lastly, remember that it’s easy to destroy and harder to protect/create. At some point, you don’t just want to be a ‘breaker’… also spend time thinking and learning how to stop someone like you, and you’re on your way to making our tech world a better place.

In computer security, a hacker is someone who focuses on security mechanisms of computer and network systems. There is a community and shared culture of expert programmers and networking wizards that traces its history back through decades to the first time-sharing minicomputers and the earliest ARPAnet experiments. The members of this culture were the first "hackers." Breaking into computers and breaking phone systems have come to symbolize hacking in popular culture, but hacking culture is much more complex and moralistic than most people know. To become a hacker, learn basic hacking techniques, how to think like a hacker, and how to gain respect within the ethical hacking community. FundamentalsA) Run a UNIX-like OS, such as Linux. UNIX and UNIX-like operating systems are the operating systems of the Internet. While you can learn to use the Internet without knowing UNIX, you can't be an Internet hacker without understanding UNIX. For this reason, the hacker culture today is pretty strongly UNIX-centered. There are many types of UNIX-like operating systems, the most popular being Linux, which you can run alongside Microsoft Windows on the same machine. Download Linux online or find a local Linux user group to help you with installation.A good way to dip your toes in the water is to boot up what Linux fans call a live CD or USB, a distribution that runs entirely off a CD or USB without modifying your hard disk. This is a way to get a look at the possibilities without having to do anything drastic.There are other UNIX-like operating systems besides Linux, such as the *BSD systems. The most popular *BSD systems are FreeBSD, NetBSD, OpenBSD and DragonFly BSD. All are open source just like Linux, however it's important to remember that they are BSD and not Linux. macOS is based on Darwin, a UNIX operating system that's based on FreeBSD. Darwin is fully free and open source and is available fromhttp://opensource.apple.com. Because the core of the system is UNIX, and macOS is very popular, many people have ported over Linux applications to macOS. You can get those programs with a package manager like homebrew, fink or macports. Alternatively, you can just run Linux on a Mac alongside macOS.If you want to get super niche, you can even run an operating system like OpenIndiana, which is based on the open source release of the Solaris operating system before it was acquired by Oracle and made closed source. OpenIndiana and Solaris are based on UNIX System V, and, as such, are not compatible with Linux applications. That said, there are many ports of Linux applications. You're probably better off just using macOS, BSD or Linux because they are much more popular and have many more programs available for them. B) Learn HTML If you don't know how to program, learning basic Hyper Text Mark-Up Language (HTML) and gradually building proficiency is essential. What you see when you look at a website of pictures, images, and design components is all coded using HTML. For a project, set out to learn how to make a basic home page and work your way up from There.in your browser, open the page source information to examine the HTML to see an example. Go to Web Developer > Page Source in Firefox and spend time looking at the code.You can write HTML in a basic word processing program like Notepad or Simple text and save your files as "text only," so you can upload them to a browser and see your work translated.You'll need to learn to format tags and learn to think visually using them. "<" is used to open a tag and "/> is used to close it. "" is the opening for a line of paragraph code. You'll use tags to signal anything visual: italics, formatting, color, etc. Learning HTML will help you to understand better how the Internet works. C) Learn the language of programming Before you start writing poems you have to learn basic grammar. Before you break the rules you have to learn the rules. But if your ultimate goal is to become a hacker, you're going to need more than basic English to write your masterpiece. Python is a good "language" to start off with because it's cleanly designed, well documented, and relatively kind to beginners. Despite being a good first language, it is not just a toy; it is very powerful, flexible, and well-suited for large projects.Java is an alternative, but its value as a first programming language has been questioned. If you get into serious programming, you will have to learn C, the core language of Unix. C++ is very closely related to C; if you know one, learning the other will not be difficult. C is very efficient with your machine's resources, but will soak up huge amounts of your time on debugging and is often avoided for that reason, unless the efficiency of your computer is especially important. It is probably a good idea to use a good starting platform such as Backtrack 5 R3, Kali or Ubuntu 12.04LTS. Hacking attitudesA) Think creatively. Now that you've got the basic skills in place, you can start thinking artistically. Hackers are like artists, philosophers, and engineers all rolled up into one. They believe in freedom and mutual responsibility. The world is full of fascinating problems waiting to be solved. Hackers take a special delight in solving problems, sharpening their skills, and exercising their intelligence.Hackers have a diversity of interests culturally and intellectually, outside of hacking. Work as intensely as you play, and play as intensely as you work. For true hackers, the boundaries between "play," "work," "science," and "art" all tend to disappear, or to merge into a high-level creative playfulness.Read science fiction. Go to science fiction conventions, which is a great way to meet hackers and proto-hackers. Consider training in a martial art. The kind of mental discipline required for martial arts seems to be similar in important ways to what hackers do. The most hacker-ly martial arts are those which emphasize mental discipline, relaxed awareness, and control, rather than raw strength, athleticism, or physical toughness. Tai Chi is a good martial art for hackers. B) Learn to love solving problems. No problem should ever have to be solved twice. Think of it as a community in which the time of everyone is hackers is precious. Hackers believe sharing information is a moral responsibility. When you solve problems, make the information public to help everyone solve the same issue. You don't have to believe that you're obligated to give all your creative product away, though the hackers that do are the ones that get most respect from other hackers. It's consistent with hacker values to sell enough of it to keep you in food and rent and computers. Read older pieces, such as the "Jargon File" or "Hacker Manifesto" by The Mentor. They may be out of date in terms of technical issues, but the attitude and spirit are just as timely. C) Learn to recognize and fight authority. The enemy of the hacker is boredom, drudgery, and authoritarian figures who use censorship and secrecy to strangle the freedom of information. Monotonous work keeps the hacker from hacking.Embracing hacking as a way of life is to reject so-called "normal" concepts of work and property, choosing instead to fight for equality and common knowledge. D) Be competent. So, anyone who spends time on Reddit can write up a ridiculous cyberpunk user name and pose as a hacker. But the Internet is a great equalizer, and values competence over ego and posture. Spend time working on your craft and not your image and you'll more quickly gain respect than modeling yourself on the superficial things we think of "hacking" in popular culture. Hacking WellA) Write open-source software. Write programs that other hackers think are fun or useful, and give the program sources away to the whole hacker culture to use. Hackerdom's most revered demigods are people who have written large, capable programs that met a widespread need and given them away, so that now everyone uses them. B) Help test and debug open-source software. Any open-source author who's thinking will tell you that good beta-testers (who know how to describe symptoms clearly, localize problems well, can tolerate bugs in a quickie release, and are willing to apply a few simple diagnostic routines) are worth their weight in rubies. Try to find a program under development that you're interested in and be a good beta-tester. There's a natural progression from helping test programs to helping debug them to helping modify them. You'll learn a lot this way, and generate goodwill with people who will help you later on. C) Publish useful information. Another good thing is to collect and filter useful and interesting information into web pages or documents like Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) lists, and make those generally available. Maintainers of major technical FAQs get almost as much respect as open-source authors. D) Help keep the infrastructure working. The hacker culture (and the engineering development of the Internet, for that matter) is run by volunteers. There's a lot of necessary but unglamorous work that needs done to keep it going — administering mailing lists, moderating newsgroups, maintaining large software archive sites, developing RFCs and other technical standards. People who do this sort of thing well get a lot of respect, because everybody knows these jobs are huge time sinks and not as much fun as playing with code. Doing them shows dedication. E) Serve the hacker culture itself. This is not something you'll be positioned to do until you've been around for a while and become well-known for one of the four previous items. The hacker culture doesn't have leaders, exactly, but it does have culture heroes and tribal elders and historians and spokespeople. When you've been in the trenches long enough, you may grow into one of these. Hackers distrust blatant ego in their tribal elders, so visibly reaching for this kind of fame is dangerous. Rather than striving for it, you have to sort of position yourself so it drops in your lap, and then be modest and gracious about your status. All the best!

Most important thing about hacking is knowing inside and out of whatever you are hacking. If you try to hack a website you will probably need to know PHP, SQL and general networking at a high level. If you want to hack games, you will need to learn how to decompile code, and how to read that decompiled code. Whatever you want to hack, you will need intimate knowledge of how it works and how it’s made. So aside from learning about technologies that make your target, you will need to learn how to think like hacker. What to look for and how to fool the system do do something it shouldn’t do. If you are serious about this (hopefully White Hat), I would suggest reading “Certified Ethical Hacker” study guide by “Wiley”. It is good place to start your carrier as a hacker. Better yet, if you finish it you can probably also pass the CEH exam. Though it is pricey ($600) it would open a lot of doors. White hat hackers are one of best paid IT profession out there. Though you should keep in mind CEH study guide will serve more as a road map. If you are just starting out you will need to learn a lot of additional information. However, if you just want to mess around (Gray Hat), you might like to read “Game Hacking” by “No Starch Press” or “The Web Application Hacker’s Handbook” by “Wiley”. These are more specialised and will let you “get down and dirty” faster. Forums. Hacking is very dynamic area of IT. Newest methods and vulnerabilities can get patched in matter of hours so outdated information is useless in most cases. That’s why many hackers discuss what they learn on forums. Though don’t expect everyone to reveal all their secrets or that there will be step-by-step guides. Forums is a great place to find information that isn’t available (yet) in books but you will need to do a lot of “sifting” as not all information is reliable and I wouldn’t suggest downloading any tools on forums until you are more familiar with what is going on the forum (who is trusted, etc.) Personally, I haven’t had good experience with YouTube. You might find some “How to hack WPA2 router” guides but generally you will learn faster by reading and playing around.

“Don’t learn to hack, hack to learn.” If your goal are malicious in nature, nobody will help you get there.That being said, let’s go on. Learn about computers, how they work and how to really use them.It’s a self-learning adventure though. It’s already so time consuming for someone to learn and acquire hacking knowledge and skills than that person don’t have time to teach for free what has been acquired with really hard work.You can pay for professional training by recognized computer security practitioners, but these won’t be replacement for hard work. The first and really best friend of a hacker is Google and the internet.You can learn anything from it if you’re willing to put the effort.There are many resources out there. If you’re not willing to put in the effort, you won’t be a hacker.It’s really hard work.Instead of doing some stuffs, you write code … A lot of people will depends only on hacking tools … while hacking tools don’t do everything. They’re only part of the equation. Writing and understanding code are an important aspect of hacking into computers even though it’s not always necessary.If you’re able to think past the tools and more about what you know and exploit your knowledge to go further or learn what’s needed, you’ll be farther apart from others.Your tools are what makes hacking possible, but if you can’t write your own tools and need to wait for someone to write them for you or depend so much on tools that you’d be stuck without them … well, in my humble opinion you’re not really a hacker.You use the right tools for the right work, or write one or find another solution. There is always another way in. A hacker won’t depend on one technique or one tool, but it will have an arsenal of tools or techniques that are public or privately written and be able to juggle between many of them.It has more to do with thinking about solutions to break something or an assumption.The more you’ll hack, the more you’ll know how to hack. I did OSCP (Offensive Security Certified Professional), and the people who were the most efficient was because they tweaked their way of thinking, using tools, analyzing data and writing custom code if needed.They didn’t only depend on premade tools to tell them where the vulnerabilities are.If you can’t hack manually without tools, and get stuck and give up at any roadblock, you are and won’t be a computer hacker. Hacking is not as easy as people say it is but it’s not as hard as people think it is too.Depends how deep you want to go into the rabbit hole. If you want to use exploits, it’s pretty easy.If you want to write them, it’s a whole other story. You want to write exploits?Writing exploits for a web-app is a whole lot different than writing an exploit for native applications.If you didn’t understand that paragraph, be curious and go get a look around. Some of characteristics of hackers : curious, motivated, autonomous, creative, etc.If you expect to be spoonfed or have a lot of hand-holding, then you are not and won’t be a hacker.A true and real hacker do ask help when needed, but don’t expect to be spoonfed. And to finish, the best hackers out there don’t all have certifications.

Install any operating system based on *nix family. (Delete windows, either it is genuine or not, it doesn’t matter) First, it's not easy to be a hacker or security expert.It's a long process and hard work of lots of years, it won’t come in just one night or one day or one month or even one year. One must be a very passionate, curious and hard worker. Learn to use Linux or Unix using Command-line Interface only (no GUI as there is no learning in GUI, if need GUI then use windows) and then after doing a lots of practice, learn Linux system administration.Learn shell and python scripting language (useful in developing security tools and automating tasks)Learn computer networking, Linux Networking Concepts which includes Wireless networking, protocols, OS/TCP-IP stack, IPTABLES, IDS/IPS, etc.Learn NMAP Scripting Engine & Pentesting Tools (NMAP, Wireshark, aircrack suite etc.) and security framework 'Metasploit' and do lots of practice.Try to get your hands dirty in Kali Linux but please, don’t limit yourself to only Kali Linux (because you can also do that with every distro of Linux family)Learn server security hardening or learn to protect your servers, in other words, *nix security administration.Must learn Programming languages like C/C++, ARM/x86/x64 assembly language, which helps in development (code and memory optimization), shellcode development, reversing malware, software and also in software exploitation).Learn about socket programming in Python and C, both. It would be helpful in the development of backdoors and shellcodes.Learn about operating system concepts, about Linux and BSDs and their security implementation on OS to make them secure.Learn kernel programming which includes driver development from both, theoretical and practical point of view.It would be little difficult to learn kernel programming as it requires one to be proficient in C, *nix system engineering (user-space development), some assembly language and all other operating system concepts. In kernel programming one will learn more about the internals of os and kernel like how everything inside the kernel works. Note: Whatever stuff I have written here is more focussed on System and Network Security.Please don't take it so easy,it requires a lot of hard work to be an independent security expert.Do lots of research (or re-search on google) and learn by own. Don’t depend or wait for someone to teach or spoon-feed. Everyone is busy and struggling with their own problems in life.Do a lot of practice on each and every point that mentioned above by setting up the virtual labs or in dockers or some sort of hardware, whatever suits.Learn and read a lot of security technical books and also practice them a lot because technical books are not novels.This post doesn’t cover mobile pentesting (user-space) and web pentesting. I am not the right person for web or on mobile pentesting yet but still mentioning some; like learning web development languages, learn about OWASP and also web-based attacks and try HackerOne or Bugcrowd to practice etc.) For mobile pentesting like app reversing etc. one can proceed after learning the points mentioned above. Requirements: Google.Curious Mind.Patience .Eagerness to Learn.Constant and continous learning.Never Stop Learning!!

Our society has two metrics toward greatness: wealth or notoriety. The second sort of comes with the first be default. Consider what Bill Gates, a high school student turned Harvard drop out, did: he wrote a BASIC interpreter for (some of his critics forget this) a microprocessor microcomputer which was thought not possible at that time, which he parlayed into a business. He had insight, timing, talented skill, business acumen, and throw in whatever other positive and negative adjectives you want, to become the richest man in the world to the annoyance and admiration of the old, the less talented, envious, (throw in adjectives) and the rest of us. Great hacker? Monetarily and some notoriety. So how about a hacker without wealth and some notoriety. How about Stallman? He's doing GNU. He's skilled; his accomplishments earned him a MacArthur Fellowship. Hacking is poorly understood. Some people think it's about cracking into computers. Hardily. As one start, it helps to read Levy's book. His account starts with physical systems (model rail roads). In computers, it involved hardware and machine language not higher level languages (which had to fight for the rights to compete with the lower-level languages guys). It's not about languages. It's about problem solving (eeeee, some say outside the box).  So the questions are: what are you going to do? And how are you going to do it? Context: I've been given a card which states that I'm a card carrying Unix hacker. I'm not fully certain how I deserve that (well, ... yes, I do to a small degree, but I can't believe to the degree of some of my friends). And I am continually reaffirmed by colleagues that I should attend hacker gatherings despite the fact that I'm retired and have no where near the skills of some of them (they say I'm a life hacker (I don't buy that)). I think they want me as a foil on calling them foils. (Manish, you and Mark upvoted (I got his note but don't see the tally) way too early. I had not finished this.) I'm a minor hacker blessed to know a few greats.

As the hacker is among the most skilled information technology disciplines, it requires a wide knowledge of IT technologies and techniques. To truly be a great hacker, one must master many skills. Don't be discouraged if you don't have all the skills I list here, but rather use this list as a starting ground for what you need to study and master in the near future. The Fundamental Skills These are the basics that every hacker should know before even trying to hack. Once you have a good grasp on everything in this section, you can move into the intermediary level. Basic Computer Skills It probably goes without saying that to become a hacker you need some basic computer skills. These skills go beyond the ability to create a Word document or cruise the Internet. You need to be able to use the command line in Windows, edit the registry, and set up your networking parameters. Many of these basic skills can be acquired in a basic computer skills course like A+. Networking Skills You need to understand the basics of networking, such as the following. DHCPNATSubnettingIPv4IPv6Public v Private IPDNSRouters and switchesVLANsOSI modelMAC addressingARPLinux Skills It is extremely critical to developing Linux skills to become a hacker. Nearly all the tools we use as a hacker are developed for Linux and Linux gives us capabilities that we don't have using Windows. If you need to improve your Linux skills, or you're just getting started with Linux, check out my Linux series for beginners below. Virtualization You need to become proficient in using one of the virtualization software packages such as VirtualBox or VMWare Workstation. Ideally, you need a safe environment to practice your hacks before you take them out in the real world. A virtual environment provides you with a safe environment to test and refine your hacks before going live with them. Cryptography Although one doesn't need to be a cryptographer to be a good hacker, the more you understand the strengths and weaknesses of each cryptographic algorithm, the better the chances of defeating it. In addition, cryptography can be used by the hacker to hide their activities and evade detection. Reverse Engineering Reverse engineering enables you to open a piece of malware and re-build it with additional features and capabilities. Just like in software engineering, no one builds a new application from scratch. Nearly every new exploit or malware uses components from other existing malware. In addition, reverse engineering enables the hacker to take an existing exploit and change its signature so that it can fly past IDS and AV detection. Think Creatively There is ALWAYS a way to hack a system and many ways to accomplish it. A good hacker can think creatively of multiple approaches to the same hack. Persistence A hacker must be persistent. If you fail at first, try again. If that fails, come up with a new approach and try again. It is only with a persistence that you will be able to hack the most secure systems.

This is for educational purposes only: That depends on what you are trying to accomplish with your hack. Let’s assume you’re targeting websites: I would suggest starting by doing a bit of recon work on your target. By recon, I mean, sniff for open ports, determine what software and versions are being utilized in your target server. Let’s assume you want to attack from the admin login page. You can do several things to make yourself more successful; Check the source code, search for scripts that collect input from the user, and determine how the website will respond to unusual input. In the case of an admin login page, input: ADMIN’ OR 1=1# for Website/admin/login pages. However, you can also include SQL statements with your input, try to execute a command specific to the OS the server is running. Try to determine the filters for input the site has in place and what ways you can bypass them. One could also try SQLi or SQL(Simple Query Language) injection. What this means is attacking a data-driven app by inserting malicious SQL statements into an entry field and executing them. Many sites are vulnerable to this attack and a simple google search for php?id=1 will show you which ones. To delve much further, I’d basically be hacking the site for you. Try out some different techniques; Preferrably in a website you own or have been given permission to penetration test. Reminder: This is for educational purposes only.

Let me start by telling you the story of the first hacker ever. Once, there was a king who was looking for a hacker but he knew nothing about the procedure to hire one. So, he came up with a strategy. He placed a large boulder in the middle of the main road, completely blocking entry into the city. Then, he hid nearby to see how people react to it. To the king's disappointment there came people after people but they cursed the king and moved on. No one did anything to move that rock. King was really disappointed. After many weeks, there came a villager, lone peasant. He did not turn away, instead he strained and strained trying to push it out of his way. Then he had his "Eureka" moment. He started looking for something to use as lever. Finally, he found a long branch that he used to dislodge the massive rock. Beneath the rock was a pot of gold. And, the king found his hacker.  Hackers are people like that peasant, they look through the problems, it is nothing more than how you use resources to move forward. And there is no one way that fits all, different hackers use different tools to perform same action. Now, if you want to be a hacker - find a challenge and sweat your brains to find a way! Be well <3

To be a good hacker, i.e. one who has a lot of skill, you must specialize in one or several topics, and also know the basics of the others. For example, you could specialize in exploit research and development for Windows, Linux and/or OS X, but still be able to conduct penetration tests professionally against web apps, web services, external networks, internal networks, etc. That is only part of the equation though. As a professional hacker (i.e. penetration tester / security consultant) working full-time, you must also be able to follow a decent methodology so your testing results are consistent and of high quality. If you don’t, then you’re really doing bug bounties, and not penetration testing. Another key factor to becoming or being a good hacker, and this is probably the most important; you must understand how your attack works, why it works, and in most cases when it’s within your area of expertise, how to patch it yourself. As a professional penetration tester, you must also be able to explain the same type of issue in various formats from technical to another pentester, to a beginner pentester, to an infosec manager, to a developer, and perhaps to a non-technical user. Within this particular skill set, your report writing skills should also be good. This is something that most people learn when they get their first job in pentesting, even though I have seen some firms produce reports that look like someone with one day of experience wrote it. While reporting is not always funny (especially if there are lots of bugs as that means more work) and you still have the same deadline to meet in most cases (at least in mine), the report is after all the final product the client pays for and receives. You might have a debriefing after the report has been issued, maybe even two in case they don’t understand the report. So, if you want to be a good professional hacker, it’s not just about learning a few tricks, it’s also how you work, how you deliver the results, and how you communicate with the client for example. Having very good English skills is probably one of the best things you can do for yourself, as it will open up job opportunities world wide, and you will also be able to pick up information much faster and communicate effectively with other hackers.
