Being a hacker is multidisciplinary. Computer technology is a little complex, but less so than say equivalent levels of biology, psychology, or law. Most companies making technology only put as much effort into their products as the market will bear and their competitors are doing. If you know more, dig deeper, and try harder than they do, you can compromise technology systems. Some things to do include understanding in detail– The layers of computing– hardware and networks, hypervisor, operating system, middleware and databases, APIs and libraries, applications, and user interfacesDevelopment– computer science theory, programming languages, processors and how they execute codeInformation Security and Risk Management– how systems are protected and compromised, what risks have a highest likelihood of successful exploitationOrganizational methodology– understand how a target organization operates including- how they hire, promote, work patterns, schedules, communication, management structure, processes, and endpoint, application and access rights provisioning, credential issuance and revocation, key management, and security architectureOnce you know more than those making the hardware and software in their fields, or even if you can achieve a unique view they haven't considered, you can use that knowledge to overcome the controls. Too many organizations throw security technology as bandaids at the problems instead of trying to understand and close the vulnerabilities.

Being a hacker has nothing to do with a particular technology. It is a way of thinking. One of the best ways to describe it is to quote one of my favourite films:  "What you must learn is that these rules are no different than the rules of a computer system. Some of them can be bent, others can be broken." - Morpheus, The Matrix. Hackers are great cheaters. Information Security expert Bruce Schneier talks more about this mindset here (http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2012/06/teaching_the_se.html). Hackers are patient. They are willing to take their time to achieve their outcome. They are the digital version of a master sniper, waiting for two days without food or water and sleeping in their own filth for the one moment when the set of circumstances they require are present. Then they carefully and calmly go for the kill shot. The best hackers - unlike most "technology people" - have an excellent understanding of human behavior and how to manipulate it. They know that the weakest link in any security system is the people involved. Finally, great hackers have great memories - for details, and yes, lots of technology information. They are often "jack-of-all-trades and master of nearly all of them" people. So, how can you become a hacker? 1. Learn to cheat at everything.2. Learn to be patient and how to change tactics quickly in the face of adversity until you succeed.3. Learn to understand people, their motivations, and how to manipulate them.4. Learn how to remember vast quantities of information, particularly about technology.

You didn't define who a hacker is to you. If you want to break into computers and commit fraud/vandalism, I'm one of the good guys and I've been studying how to make computers do what I want (including security) since a was a kid in the 1980s.  You'll have to be skilled enough and lucky enough to catch me making a serious mistake in order to break in to my systems.  I think you will find this to be an exercise in futility, and I won't help you make unnecessary work for me. If, on the other hand, hacking means "building circuits and making your own computers" I can and will help you! What you want is a Raspberry Pi.  It runs Linux (which is something you need to know in order to understand computers), and the community behind it is really enthusiastic about teaching engineering to anyone who wants to learn.  Also, while it's not the fastest computer, it's one of the cheapest and most flexible computers you can buy. I recommend the Raspberry Pi route.  Hacking with them is more likely to land you in engineering school than in jail, and you'll be a far more knowledgeable hacker in the end. P.S. The stories about what hackers can do come from the 1960s and 1970s.  One of the things that has changed in the half century since those stories were forged is that the pros take computer security seriously enough that it has become own highly skilled specialty in the IT world, and in law enforcement.  I've worked with and taken classes from a few of those guys over the years, and they're very serious professionals.

It largely depends on what you mean by hacker. Classically, if you're talking about developing an ability to pull off criminal activities using a computer, that is generally called cracking (at least it used to be). Hacker always kind of meant computer enthusiast (back when not everybody had computers), and is adopted by outfits like Facebook more recently to mean hardcore programmers. There are hardware hackers, people modding everything from boards onward to create performance or tools not intended by original manufacturers. But if you mean the idea of hacker as technical security expert, than the answer is to learn. Learn a Unix based OS, learn a programming language from the standpoint of understanding the basics of all languages (C, Python, etc.), learn basic networking protocols. Start hanging out in forums dealing with technical security, reading blogs on the same, and attend the right conferences (ShmooCon is coming up). And when you're done with all that, start original research and contribute back to the security community via blogs, small gatherings, presentations, and so forth. Most certifications (I have a few) won't put you within a light year of being "a hacker", the way to earn that role is via respect from the community based on contributions. Or...if you want the media to call you a hacker, do something criminal even if it's basic, make sure it gets a lot of attention, and then get caught/do time.  ;)

Businesses and government-related organizations that are serious about their network security hire ethical hackers and penetration testers to help probe and improve their networks, applications, and other computer systems with the ultimate goal of preventing data theft and fraud. You may not get the same adrenaline rush that you might with underground hacking, but you can earn a good and honest living--and not end up facing prison time, as some illegal "black hat" hackers do. How does the job market look like for ethical hackers? Extremely good! The IT market overall continues to grow despite the current economic turmoil. Research firm Gartner estimates that worldwide enterprise IT spending grew by 5.9 percent between 2009 and 2010, to a total of $2.7 trillion. At the same time, security is becoming a more pressing concern. Gartner expects to see an increase of nearly 40 percent in spending on worldwide security services during the five-year period from 2011 to 2015, eventually surpassing $49.1 billion. In your first years as an ethical hacker, you'll be in a position to earn anywhere from $50,000 to $100,000 per year, depending on the company that hires you, and on your IT experience and education. With several years of professional experience, you could command $120,000 or more per year, especially if you do your own independent consulting. You can't just dive into an ethical hacker position, however. Without IT security experience, you won't get very far, even with degrees and certifications. As is true for other IT jobs, employers typically want candidates who have college degrees, but related experience is king. And experience with certifications can typically take the place of some degree requirements.

I think you're born with it, or not. There's this deep curiosity, an intense desire to know "how does this work" or "what's in there" or "what would happen if I did X...". It just doesn't go away. You can suppress it in polite company, but sooner or later, the tools come out and you dive in... It usually manifests when you're very young, and you start asking adults questions about how stuff works, and they either ignore you or give you patently wrong information. So you set off to figure it out for yourself.  And nothing breeds excess like success, so the first time you score a win, and successfully disassemble and dissect and reassemble (and improve!) something that's not supposed to come apart in the first place,  that's a powerful motivation to rinse and repeat. In the day before computers were commonplace, that lead to a infinity of mechanical inventions. Edison, Tesla, Ford , Watt, Newton, Galileo, da Vinci - those guys and countless hundreds more were "ur Hackers".  My son got an iPad when he was what, three? Four? He's been asking questions about how stuff works for a long time, and is starting to get to the taking things apart to see what makes them tick stage. I keep heading him off at the pass when it gets to consumer electronics, where you really do need to have special tools to make any sense of it, but readily give him dead boards and parts to examine. It's just a matter of time before that turns to software. I'm in favor, in case that wasn't obvious.

Firstly, let's understand.. What is a hacker? There is a community, a shared culture, of expert programmers and networking wizards that traces its history back through decades to the first time-sharing minicomputers and the earliest ARPAnet experiments. The members of this culture originated the term ‘hacker’. Hackers built the Internet. Hackers made the Unix operating system what it is today. Hackers make the World Wide Web work. A Hacker's Attitude: the following modern Zen poem has it: To follow the path: look to the master, follow the master, walk with the master, see through the master, become the master. So, if you want to be a hacker, repeat the following things until you believe them. Now I have a list of facts that you must realise in order to be a hacker! The world is full of fascinating problems waiting to be solved.No problem should ever have to be solved twice.Boredom and drudgery are evil.Freedom is good.Attitude is no substitute for competence.Basic Hacking Skills that you must develop in order to step in the Hacking World! Learn How To ProgramThis, of course, is the fundamental hacking skill. If you don't know any computer languages, I recommend starting with Python. It is cleanly designed, well documented, and relatively kind to beginners. Get one of the open-source Unixes and learn to use and run it.I'll assume you have a personal computer or can get access to one. (Take a moment to appreciate how much that means. The hacker culture originally evolved back when computers were so expensive that individuals could not own them.) Unix is the operating system of the Internet. While you can learn to use the Internet without knowing Unix, you can't be an Internet hacker without understanding Unix. Learn how to use the World Wide Web and write HTML.Most of the things the hacker culture has built do their work out of sight, helping run factories and offices and universities without any obvious impact on how non-hackers live. The Web is the one big exception, the huge shiny hacker toy that even politicians admit has changed the world. If you don't have functional English, learn it.However, being a native English-speaker does not guarantee that you have language skills good enough to function as a hacker. If your writing is semi-literate, ungrammatical, and riddled with misspellings, many hackers (including myself) will tend to ignore you. The Hacker/Nerd Connection Contrary to popular myth, you don't have to be a nerd to be a hacker. It does help, however, and many hackers are in fact nerds. Being something of a social outcast helps you stay concentrated on the really important things, like thinking and hacking. Also, if you're partially through all this then the question you should be asking yourself is that, How do I tell if I am already a hacker? 🙂 Happy Hacking!

Hackers come from a variety of different educational backgrounds. Some have four-year computer science degrees, while others are self-taught. In the past few years, hacker training programs have become another viable option for those interested in entering the field. There are now several hacker “boot camps” across the country that train people who have little to no programming experience. Becoming a successful hacker depends on building a base of knowledge and computer programming skills. One of the most important areas of knowledge for hackers is computer networking. Hackers must know how computers communicate with each other through the Internet and internal networks, so they should be very familiar with the protocols on which these networks are built. Hackers should also be very familiar with the security measures used to protect computer networks. Programming plays an important role in hacking, and hackers should know how to read and write code written in different programming languages. They should also work in different operating systems, like Windows, Unix, Linux, and Mac OS X. Many hackers work extensively on Unix and Linux operating systems because many servers are Unix or Linux-based, and because these operating systems give end users a great deal of freedom to explore and manipulate. Computer systems are maintained and operated by humans, so many hackers also develop skills in what is called “social engineering.” Social engineering involves gaining the trust of the users and guardians of a computer network and manipulating that trust to gain access to it. A hacker may gain physical access to a server room, for example, by misrepresenting himself to employees in the building, or gain access to a network by convincing a user to give him their password. No matter their training, hackers gain experience and credibility through practice and collaboration with the hacker community. Hackers can contribute to the knowledge in their field by writing and sharing software tools, testing software written by others, and writing documentation. Are there any certification or licensure requirements? There are no licensure requirements to become a hacker, but there are many voluntary certifications that could enhance your chances of finding a job in the field. There are many general IT certifications you can pursue to show your expertise in areas of knowledge like hardware maintenance (CompTIA’s A+ certification), networking (CompTIA’s Network+ certification and the Cisco Certified Network Professional certification), and computer security (CompTIA’s Security+ certification and the CISSP certification). Earning one of these certifications typically involves self-study, though many organizations offer training courses, and passing an exam. You can also become a Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH). The International Council of E-Commerce Consultants (EC-Council) developed the Certified Ethical Hacker program, which is now recognized by the Department of Defense as an approved training program and certification for its computer network defenders. To become a CEH, you should already have some experience in computer security. The CEH course lasts five days and includes hands-on training in topics like network scanning, intrusion, intrusion detection, social engineering, and various types of cyber attacks, such as viruses, buffer overflows, and DDoS attacks. At the end of the course, you can take an exam to earn your certification

There is a community and shared culture of expert programmers and networking wizards that traces its history back through decades to the first time-sharing minicomputers and the earliest ARPAnet experiments. The members of this culture were the first "hackers." Breaking into computers and breaking phone systems have come to symbolize hacking in popular culture, but hacking culture is much more complex and moralistic than most people know. To become a hacker, learn basic hacking techniques, how to think like a hacker, and how to gain respect within the ethical hacking community.Part One of Three:FundamentalsRun Unix. Unix is the operating system of the Internet. While you can learn to use the Internet without knowing Unix, you can't be an Internet hacker without understanding Unix. For this reason, the hacker culture today is pretty strongly Unix-centered. A Unix like Linux can run alongside Microsoft Windows on the same machine. Download Linux online or find a local Linux user group to help you with installation.[1]A good way to dip your toes in the water is to boot up what Linux fans call a live CD, a distribution that runs entirely off a CD without having to modify your hard disk. This is a way to get a look at the possibilities without having to do anything drastic.There are other operating systems besides Unix, but they're distributed in binary — you can't read the code, and you can't modify it. Trying to learn to hack on a Microsoft Windows machine or under any other closed-source system is like trying to learn to dance while wearing a body cast.Under Mac OS X it's possible to run Linux, but only part of the system is open source — you're likely to hit a lot of walls, and you have to be careful not to develop the bad habit of depending on Apple's proprietary code.Write HTML. If you don't know how to program, learning basic HyperText Mark-Up Language (HTML) and gradually building proficiency is essential. What you see when you look at a website of pictures, images, and design components is all coded using HTML. "" is the opening for a line of paragraph code. C++ is very closely related to C; if you know one, learning the other will not be difficult. Now that you've got the basic skills in place, you can start thinking artistically. Hackers are like artists, philosophers, and engineers all rolled up into one. They believe in freedom and mutual responsibility. The world is full of fascinating problems waiting to be solved. Hackers take a special delight in solving problems, sharpening their skills, and exercising their intelligence.Hackers have a diversity of interests culturally and intellectually, outside of hacking. Work as intensely as you play, and play as intensely as you work. For true hackers, the boundaries between "play," "work," "science," and "art" all tend to disappear, or to merge into a high-level creative playfulness.Read science fiction. Go to science fiction conventions, which is a great way to meet hackers and proto-hackers. Consider training in a martial art. The kind of mental discipline required for martial arts seems to be similar in important ways to what hackers do. The most hacker-ly martial arts are those which emphasize mental discipline, relaxed awareness, and control, rather than raw strength, athleticism, or physical toughness. Tai Chi is a good martial art for hackers.Learn to love solving problems. No problem should ever have to be solved twice. Think of it as a community in which the time of everyone is hackers is precious. Hackers believe sharing information is a moral responsibility. When you solve problems, make the information public to help everyone solve the same issue.You don't have to believe that you're obligated to give all your creative product away, though the hackers that do are the ones that get most respect from other hackers. It's consistent with hacker values to sell enough of it to keep you in food and rent and computers.Read older pieces, such as the "Jargon File" or "Hacker Manifesto" by The Mentor. They may be out of date in terms of technical issues, but the attitude and spirit are just as timely.[5]Learn to recognize and fight authority.The enemy of the hacker is boredom, drudgery, and authoritarian figures who use censorship and secrecy to strangle the freedom of information. Monotonous work keeps the hacker from hacking.Embracing hacking as a way of life is to reject so-called "normal" concepts of work and property, choosing instead to fight for equality and common knowledge.Be competent. So, anyone who spends time on Reddit can write up a ridiculous cyberpunk user name and pose as a hacker. But the Internet is a great equalizer, and values competence over ego and posture. Spend time working on your craft and not your image and you'll more quickly gain respect than modeling yourself on the superficial things we think of "hacking" in popular culture. I think first you need to separate between what you mean by hacking and then what you mean by ethical hacking. If you are saying "can I be an ethical hacker, I know C++" you might be talking about the traditional definition of hacking, which is someone who likes to program and explore technology for the sheer joy of it. A homebrew computer hobbyist or a budding amateur engineer. The trend in computing in the popular imagination lately is that people who like to explore technology are in someways "unethical" because they do it for their own edification. For example, if you are "hacking" a new program to control your home automation system because you don't like the software they supply with the devices, that's somehow unethical because the company whose products you bought didn't give you permission to play with the technology you rightfully own.  I my book, the current trend towards this "mother may I?" approach to technology just kills interest in STEM and suppresses the natural curiosity of people disposed to become engineers because of a vague, ill-defined notion of "intellectual property." If this is what you mean by hacking, you are an ethical hacker by definition, ignore anybody who tells you otherwise. If you are talking about information security and being an "ethical hacker," you are like many people, responding to marketing from people who sell certifications. That's good for them because the commercial purpose for that marketing is to make everyone have that insecurity. If you aren't an ethical hacker, you must by definiton live in some grey area, right? It's so lucky that a large, plodding certification body can wave a magic wand and make you ethical because you passed their multiple-choice test. See the problem? Now, don't get me wrong, those certifications have their place. The do provide a low level of assurance that a person is familiar with a defined body of knowledge that is acceptable by the industry as the lowest common denominator. They are helpful when you need to get past the HR department to get a job. However, what that industry means by ethical hacking is that you use tools to help defend people's information assets, either by testing for vulnerabilities, doing forensics, or performing root cause analysis to help avoid future breaches. Unfortunately, threats evolve so quickly that there's a good chance that many of the tools people certify on will be obsolete by the time they complete the certification. As my grandfather used to say "use the right tool for the job," and if you don't know any better because there's a tool you are certified on that you are supposed to be using because "it's the ethical thing," then you might be need a more evolved sense of professional ethics overall. In short, don't believe the hype about ethical hacking.

These are the basics Skill for the beginner to become Hacker. 1. Basic Computer Skills It probably goes without saying that to become a hacker you need some basic computer skills. Many of these basic skills can be acquired in a basic computer skills course like A+. 2. Networking Skills You need to understand the basics of networking, such as the following. DHCP NAT Subnetting Difference between IPv4 or IPv6 Public v Private IP DNS Routers and switches VLANs OSI model MAC addressing ARP Many Skill can be acquired in these certificate course like CCIE: Cisco Certified Internetwork Expert & CompTIA Network+ . 3. Linux Skills Nearly all the tools we use as a hacker are developed for Linux and Linux gives us capabilities that we don't have using Windows. Here is the eBook that help you to learn more about Linux: Click Here 4. Wireshark or Tcpdump Wireshark is the most widely used sniffer/protocol analyzer, while tcpdump is a command line sniffer/protocol analyzer. Both are useful in analyzing TCP/IP traffic and attacks. 5. Virtualization You need to become proficient in using one of the virtualization software packages such as VirtualBox or VMWare Workstation. Ideally, you need a safe environment to practice your hacks before you take them out in real world. 6. Security Concepts & Technologies A good hacker understands security concepts and technologies. The hacker must understand such things as PKI (public key infrastructure), SSL (secure sockets layer), IDS (intrusion detection system), firewalls, etc. The beginner hacker can acquire many of these skills in a basic security course such as Security+. 7. Wireless Technologies In order to be able to hack wireless, you must first understand how it works. Things like the encryption algorithms (WEP, WPA, WPA2), the four-way handshake, and WPS. In addition, understanding such as things as the protocol for connection and authentication and the legal constraints on wireless technologies. To get started, check out my guide below on getting started with wireless terms and technologies, then read our collection of Wi-Fi hacking guides for further information on each kind of encryption algorithms and for examples of how each hack works.

You don't. Bro, trust me I have experienced both good and shit as a hacker. And the best advice that I can give you, is don't go for shortcuts. I know there are plenty of people out there, some of whom are pro hackers and often more experienced than me, who will say, “follow these simple steps and become a hacker” or maybe, “the 10 most important steps to become a hacker”, but I feel by following those you will only achieve a certain amount of success and be limited to that only. It is as they say, “There is no stairway to heaven”. So I don't think following steps is in the best interest of a novice hacker. Here's what I did as a novice and what I suggest you do. Firstly, LEARN. Always Learn. Learn from your mistakes. Learn from others' mistakes. If you hack into something, learn why that worked or why it didn't work. Learn how to fix it. Learn how to break into it. Absorb as much as you possibly can from the Cyberspace. Secondly, PRACTICE. Keep Practicing. The worst thing you can do is learn a lot then practice none. Sharpening of skills is very important. If you aren't doing that, signs of rust will show in your skills. And that's bad. So practicing is important. Lastly, Be TENACIOUS. In this line of work, you will experience more failure than success. Inevitably so. So take your failures sportingly. Learn from them. And that will make you a better hacker. And so that is all……If you manage to do these 3 simple but effective steps, you will be a better hacker someday. And also, stop looking for shortcuts. They won't get you anywhere.

response.answer_text: "Hacking" is a very broad term. You have to figure out what you like. I'll tell you what I was told when I was starting out. Hacking, at its core, is making things work in ways they weren't intended to function. Before you can do that, you need to learn how things work. Get a Raspberry Pi, learn how to navigate the Linux command line. Spin up a web server. Build a Web application. Connect it to a database. Fuzz it, see what breaks. Fix it so it doesn't break again. Then try to break it a different way. Repeat. Learn a programming language. Learn ALL the programming languages you can. Play with sockets. Learn how applications connect to each other. Learn networking. You'll start to understand how the Internet works. Design your own protocol. Build a client/server application around it. Use a network analyzer to see your protocol over the wire. It's really cool. Throw data at your server. See how it breaks. Fix it so it doesn't break again. Repeat. Learn about cryptography. Implement an algorithm in your program. Make a file encryption utility. Design a protocol to send data securely over the wire. Then break it. Fix it so it doesn't break that way again. Repeat. It boils down to a pattern. Learn, build, learn, break, learn, fix, learn. And, most importantly, have fun with it!

response.answer_text: Hacking is not overnight thing or a onetime thing. It has a slow learning process. First of all, most people are confused what actually hacking is. Its not bypassing the login screen, or gaining unauthorized access to a remote system using some script you found on the internet. It is understanding the in and out the working of a system and then modifying it according to your needs. This is one awesome guide, that helps you understand the basic hacker attitude: How To Become A Hacker. Moreover, to get started, you should start understanding technology in general and how things works, especially if you are into software/web hacking, you should understand what is a server, how does a server works, what were the  vulnerabilities in old servers and how they overcame them. To exploit a new server you must understand vulnerabilities found in old system. How does XSS work etc. Its useless if you just copy paste SQL Injection from the internet, if you don't understand what SQL queries are and how they work. And yes, programming, learn programming/scripting and become expert in one of them. Hope this helps. Happy hacking.

You can start by Reading this book, it's one of the best books ever published that's gives you information in such scale. The Web Application Hacker's Handbook: Finding and Exploiting Security Flaws This book is a practical guide to discovering and exploiting security flaws in web applications. By “web applications” the book means those that are accessed using a web browser to communicate with a web server. While I was watching Mr. Robot, whenever Eliot used to perform an attack I used to pause and carefully note down the methods he was using. This wasn't much difficult  to figure out as I've been in security field for a while now. On seeing this question I decided to google again about 'Hacks made by Eliot in Mr.Robot' and realized a lot has already been written about them. So, here are the details:  DeepSoundIf you’re wondering why someone who’d fry his computer’s memory chip in the microwave would be careless enough to store evidence of people he’s hacked on CD-ROMs disguised as CDs, then Elliot’s one step ahead of you. He usedDeepSound, an audio converter tool, to hide all of the files on everyone he’s hacked—as well as his own old family photos—within WAV and FLAC audio files. And yes, the real files are encrypted and password protected, as we saw in episode 9. DeepSound is a modern example of steganography, the art of concealing information within plain sight. ProtonMailIf you assumed Elliot would run his own server or be an early adopter of Pond , episode 8’s revelation that he has aProtonMail account may have come as a surprise. ProtonMail is a browser-based email service incorporated in Switzerland created by researchers who met at a CERN research facility. (Yes, that CERN: the one where the World Wide Web was born.) “One of the benefits of ProtonMail is that it’s end-to-end encryption, and it’s in a way that even the owners of ProtonMail can’t see your content, and there’s no IP logging,” says Michael Bazzell, one of the technical advisers on the show. It even lets you set expiration dates for your emails, after which they’ll self-destruct (provided the recipient hasn’t made a copy of them, that is). ProtonMail is free, though there’s a wait list for invitations to create an account. Beta versions of iOS and Android mobile apps were just announced, and it’s possible to jump the queue with a $29 donation. The next batch will be released Thursday. Raspberry PiARaspberry Pi is that tiny and delightfully inexpensive computer that helps you learn programming and build your own digital toys. Turns out, it can also be used to gain remote access to HVAC systems. On the show, Elliot’s plot was to gain access using the Pi and then raise the temperature in Evil Corp’s storage room where tape backups are stored, thus destroying the records of much of the consumer debt in the world. Tastic RFID ThiefFsociety wouldn’t even think of trying to penetrate the most secure facility in the country without a plan for stealing badge information from employees. Luckily, when visiting Steel Mountain, fSociety member Mobley was armed with Bishop Fox’sTastic RFID Thief, a long-range radio frequency identification (RFID) reader that saves your score on a microSD card as a text file so you can clone the badge later. It’s completely portable and fits neatly into a messenger bag or a briefcase. RSA SecurIDTwo-factor authentication can definitely foil your average fraudster’s plans. Like 25,000 actual organizations worldwide, Allsafe, the cybersecurity firm where Elliot works, usesRSA SecurID. RSA SecurID’s two-factor authentication adds a layer of security to a company’s protected resources by requiring users to not only enter their RSA SecurID pin, but a one-time password generated within the app—which lasts only 60 seconds. This is why Elliot needed a multi-faceted plan to get ahold of Gideon’s phone in episode 8. First he texted him large MMS files to try to drain some of his boss’ battery, then he snagged the phone to enter that temporary authentication code at the end of the password with nary a second to spare. He certainly raised suspicion from Gideon with the clever ruse, but at least he got the job done. Kali LinuxKali Linux, BackTrack’s Linux’s successor, is a Debian-based version of Linux that’s specifically built for penetration testing and security auditing and is used in multiple episodes of Mr. Robot. It’s free, open source, and pre-installed with hundreds of pen testing programs, so it’s perfect for cracking Wi-Fi passwords, bypassing anti-virus software, and testing security vulnerabilities on your network. Many of the tools used in Mr. Robot are utilized within Kali. “That’s the benefit of Kali is that all the tools are built in,” says Bazzell. “It’s got a distribution system with everything you need.” John the RipperJohn the Ripperis a tool that Elliot used in the second episode of the show to crack Tyrell’s password. Its primary purpose is to detect weak Unix passwords, but it can crack weak passwords with several thousand (or even several million) attempts per second. John the Ripper is available within the Kali Linux platform. Metasploit and MeterpreterEpisode 6 features Rapid7’s Metasploit Framework. Metasploit is an exploit development and delivery system that allows users to create and execute exploits, typically for penetration testing. It saves hackers time because they don’t have to learn a new tool each time they want to run an exploit. Meterpreteris just one of several hundred payloads that can be used within Metasploit. It resides entirely in memory and writes nothing to disk, but can give an attacker control of their target’s system and parts of the network. It’s often used within Kali Linux on a virtual machine in Windows, or on Windows itself. Social-Engineer ToolkitTrustedSec’s Social-Engineer Toolkit is an open-source pen testing framework designed specifically for simulating social engineering attacks, such as phishing, spear phishing, credential harvesting, and more. Elliot used SMS spoofing from within SET, a module that’s unavailable on the newer versions, but Mr. Robot tech adviser Michael Bazzell said that it’s possible for users to add that package back in within the new version. FlexiSPYThis list would be remiss without the inclusion of a tool used by one of the show’s less sympathetic characters. In the third episode of Mr. Robot, Tyrell Wellick secretly installs mobile monitoring software on a lover’s Android phone. After gaining root privilege by using SuperSU, he installsFlexiSPY, a tool that lets you monitor other people’s device activities with an online portal. FlexiSPY doesn’t recover past data, but can show you anything still stored on their phone’s memory or SIM card, as well as any future. It also hides SuperSU as part of its installation. Sneaky sneaky. Source: This amazing article at Wired. Apart from the above mention methods, Eliot is a master at Social Engineering. The way his social engineering skills are portrayed remind me of Kevin Mitnick. The best hacking being hacking of people! A common misconception a lot of students take is that hacking is a profession they can just step right into. If you think about this in terms of logic the art of hacking is to break a network, break computer programs and to locate vulnerabilities, however the question is this: How do you expect to break computer programs, computer networks and vulnerabilities efficiently without specializing in the specific technology you choose to break? You can’t, and if you do then I assure you, there’ll be some gaps in your understanding which in turn can cause a weaker outcome. I am not at all saying don’t approach hacking at all. My point is that it is a field which has a lot of pre-requisite requirements. Meaning you need to know the fundamentals of networks, programming and overall exploits before you really decide to go beyond the surface. My advice: Study networks and adapt computer programming on top of this. Ensure you are fully skilled in at least one skill-set of the two and from that point you can choose to delve into the overall security of either of the topics. Overall you will inter-connect between the two. Computer networks and programming are coming closer than ever which again is going to invoke a change in the approach of attack in terms of a hacking perspective and also change the point of networking fundamentals for engineers. The real way of becoming a hacker is to start from the ground up and becoming an expert in your chosen field before deciding to specialize in the aspect of security. This way you will have a much more concrete understanding of your security practices and you will also be able to work a lot more efficiently. This is just my opinion and not at all an industry fact document. There are a lot more people who think differently to my approach, take the one which you see best and stick to it. No one person is the same in technology, we all have our natural areas of expertise and areas we wish to develop. Good luck to you!

There’s a caveat that I have to share before diving into these sites. Hacking isn’t a single subject that anyone can pick up overnight. In the title of this article, I mention hacking like a pro. This can not be accomplished after reading one article and visiting a few of these sites – the phrase is used to imply that in time and with lots of practice, you can in fact learn to hack like a pro.For our many readers that are already at that expert-hacker level, a few of these sites may not be for you. They may feel to simple and basic – for “script-kiddies” as some might say. The truth is, we all had to start somewhere, and these websites are offered as a starting point for those people just embarking down the wrote toward hackerdom.Your intention for learning how to hack is completely your own. I do not judge. However, it should be noted that there are two forms of hacking – “white hat” and “black hat”. White hat hackers call themselves “ethical hackers”, in that they find vulnerabilities simply to make systems and applications more secure for everyone. However, there’s a whole other community of hackers – the black hats – who find vulnerabilities only to exploit them as much as possible. Now that you know what sort of community you may be entering, let’s get on with the list of top sites where you can learn to hack. If you break integrity or confidentiality, or privacy of system without consent of owner then you are hacker. Breaking code, learning programming language, using some sort of software analysis of network or using social engineering to get password etc techniques use to break security Following main element of security , if you break any any one mean you are hacker. Confidentiality is “ensuring that information is accessible only to those authorized to have access” (ISO-17799) Authenticity is “the identification and assurance of the origin of information” Integrity is “ensuring that the information is accurate, complete, reliable, and is in its original form” Availability is “ensuring that the information is accessible to authorized persons when required without delay” Non-repudiation is “ensuring that a party to a contract or a communication cannot deny the authenticity of their signature on a document”

If I wanted to become a hacker I would start by learning all I can about what hackers do. And by then you should know that you’ll need fine tune your search and ask what you really want to know because “Hacker” covers way too much ground.

Start by unplugging your pc from the Internet, go to change your password and without looking type a bunch of random stuff in. Save and Reboot. Now, try to get back into your account. (Hint: have a Bootable installation disc or USB so you can manipulate some files on your OS before it boots up. Make a full backup and recovery disc before hand in case you get stuck. Once you've gotten through that, set up some virtual machines and try to exploit or run code from one virtual machine to another that doesn't have the proper credentials to access the prior. Put all your virtual machines on a private virtual network switch so you don't accidentally hack your physical machine (or worse the network it's on.) A different type of hacking you can try out is to create a password protected rar file and crack it with John the ripper. Get really good with one or two tools first, then when you hit the limit of what they can do for you, add one or two more to your bag of tricks. Happy hunting!

Some schools offer security courses that teach you how to hack so you can defend against attacks and learn that way. It's also legal to learn this way. An example school is Radford University in southwestern Virginia. They have a three part security related program that covers:1. General Security and Principles (including basic hacking)2. Networks security (defending servers, domains, and network attacks)3. Database Security (Defending databases against attacks, database attacks) They teach you how to defend by teaching you how to hack. Once you complete these classes you should also receive two security certifications from the NSA identifying you as an expert in 1 and 2 above.  I'm sure other schools have similar opportunities. This is just one I know about.

It's really a great book for a beginner to understand security concepts from scratch, filled with intuitive analogies and real-life examples. It explains what constitutes a website hack?How come a Computer, which in layman circle, usually seen as a ‘Perfect’ machine doing computations or calculations at the lightning speed, have security vulnerabilities?! Can't all websites be safe and secure always? If you have all these innocent doubts in your mind, then this is the right book for you, seeking answers in an intuitive way using layman terms wherever possible!

honestly it’s just finding new ways of using common technologies for your own personal gain. doesn’t have to be computer related. could be as simple as using a rock as a hammer. for example I didn’t like windows parental controls so i subverted the time clock by changing it in linux, so i could use windows whenever I wanted. if your goal is to get information from a data base you’re going to have know how to query it. and you have to know what to look for to see if such a database is hackable. getting aquainted with how a infosec thinks is generally a good idea but he or she is trying to think like a hacker as well to prevent you from gaining sensitive information. i had an infosec class and it gave me an idea of what to expect from most businesses with any valuable information, and the amount of complexity of the information security was astounding and elaborate. they have systems that will alert them if you are trying to do common script kiddie attacks and automatically check logs for suspicious activity on computers, they can trace ip. so you need to know basic computer security if you want to hack and not get in trouble (or just experiment on your own machines or websites).

here is a guide to become good at hacking. as you are 16 years old you have plenty of time with you. Now, to your answer. A Hacker is someone who creates hacks. A Hack is one (or all) of the below:  a creative misuse of something, especially but not necessarily a piece of technology.more generally, a creative way to overcome some annoying restrictiona piece of technology that was created in a quick and dirty way, which gets the job done with minimal efforta piece of technology that was created after a thorough though process, which gets the job done with maximum elegance and efficiency If these seem to contradict in some parts - they do. The common denominator though is creativity and disregard for the status quo. And the firm believe that "I can do that (better)". PS: I also agree with Kim Guldberg: "Hacker" is not something you get to call yourself. It's something you get called by others. PPS: according to the jargon file, a hacker was originally "someone who makes furniture with an axe".

An ethical hacker is someone who finds vulnerabilities in systems and reports them to the owner the system so that they can fix the vulnerability before it is being criminally exploited by someone with malicious intent. Many companies will pay monetary rewards - bounties - for the best vulnerability reports submitted to them. The best ethical hackers earn a lot of money on bounties (hundreds of thousands of dollars per year). If you have the intelligence and curiosity needed, you can teach yourself the art of hacking and bug hunting. I would start by reading all vulnerability reports that have been publicly disclosed. They are a great source of learning. See here: Latest Security Vulnerabilities Found, Rewarded, or Disclosed And here is a list of other useful resources for those learning ethical hacking: Useful Online Resources for New Hackers Finally a blog posting by a top hacker about what distinguishes the best bug hunters from the rest: 5 Things Top Bug Bounty Hunters Do Differently Happy hacking!

response.answer_text: Ah hacking. The one skill that can give you pure absolute power. However it is not easily obtainable. To be considered a pretty good hacker one must dedicate 7–10 years of study in a variety of technologies like OS command lines, networking, scripting, security concepts and much more. Programming is one thing, but to make a system act in a way it wasn’t meant to is a whole other level. You need to understand how it all works and then some. Even with all this you won’t be perfect, you can never be. But you can get to a point where most things are easy to hack for you but again that’ll take just short of a decade at least.

You have not asked how to learn hacking, you have asked if you can learn hacking. I am answering accordingly. Gone are those good days of low security, when servers, WiFi routers and other network equipment has no password by default and people responsible for them were happy to use them as such. What most of the so called hackers do is take advantage of other people's carelessness. Some more advanced forms make use of social engineering, phishing, vishing or simply guessing passwords. Still it's not hacking. You can definitely learn this kind of puesdo hacking. If you want to take it a notch higher, you can use readymade tools written by experts. You would still be called a “script kiddie” in hacker community. Now a days default level of security is very high and real hacking is a serious business. It takes deep knowledge of operating systems, networking protocols, networking equipment and a high level of ingenuity to find expoits in a system. In short it's not easy. Now coming to your question, whether you can learn hacking, That depends on your knowledge and dedication (and hacker mindset, ability to take risks and above all, average intelligence level if you want to get into serous hacking)

That's like asking "how can I become a medical doctor in an afternoon?" There is a ton of knowledge and practice that goes into being a hacker. Don't get me wrong.  Becoming a hacker is attainable, but you should think of it like getting a PhD.  If you want to be good, it's going to take a lot of work and a long time. There are rarely shortcuts to being awesome at anything, and this is no exception.

The question as I saw it just now in my feed was "I'm going to college for computer network and cyber security but I wanna get ahead of the game. Is there anything I can do before, during, or after college to help me." To answer that, I'd say download and build tools like nmap and Snort and metasploit, scan and hack your own systems. Look up recent vulnerabilities, build the demonstration exploits, and try them on your own computers before and after patching them. Set up a LAMP system and write an SQL injection and XSS attack - play both sides, do the attacks, examine the logs, see if you can figure out what happened and how to prevent it. Look for the shellshock attempts in your webserver logs, look for the dictionary attacks, try some yourself.

This will be a short answer, but it simply explains how a lot of hacking is done on the web: Many people are not technologically experienced and haven’t researched exactly how hacking works and how to prevent it. Therefore, one could simply learn some basic SQL or JavaScript and exploit numerous unprotected websites with common methods. If one would like to target a more significant objective, good luck. First learn common website languages, at least to a basic extent. Then, research how people protect against hackers. Look for gaps in these methods (hint: old browsers do not abide by security rules that may be defined in their code). The last thing I would like to say is that hacking scam sites is fine, but attacking something made from hard work (even if it lacks quality) for a good purpose is simply cruel. I would hate to have my work ruined because of a browser’s issues or an unpatchable security bug. Don’t do that.

Training, training, and training. Hackers are people that find security gaps in systems and try to exploit them. There are two types of hackers: White hat hackers: are hackers that work for companies or people and try to find gaps in their security systems. So those are hackers who defend systems from other hackers. And then comes the black hat hackers, who try to steal your personal infomation and data, and ask for money in exchange for not using them to harm you. If someone wants to hack, he will probably read a book or join an online forum. He should learn how do systems work, the different types of systems, and most of all, how to write the code that enters the security systems. For the first few times, a hacker will find the code and copy-paste it. However, if he keeps on trying and training, he will automatically find gaps and exploit them. This is called experience by training.

Hacking is a discipline that incorporates a wide range of concepts. For example, you need to have an understanding about Computer Networks, Database Management to actually understand what is happening and how you are trying to get into a system. There are a lot of good websites and courses available, but self reading and a lot of practice are the best ways to learn about hacking. So, I'd suggest you to look into the subjects that are needed to implement your hack. For example : to understand SQLinjection (which is almost obsolete), you'd need to have some knowledge in database querying. P.S: If anyone is trying to become a "hacker", thinking they can "hack" into Facebook or Gmail after a few weeks of efforts, please, don't even try! I mean it, don't even try! :)

First thing, don't read books. Hacking is in your heart, you will only learn it by doing stuff. People usually limit the definition of "hacking" to cracking passwords, when in fact it is so much more than that. You can get your hands dirty by starting with some simple hacks! Download some simple code, look at what functionality is not available in that piece of code and try to hack it out. Hacking is about making software programs do exactly what you want (by usually setting up a "back door"). It can take any form! Once you are comfortable with these things, you can move on to bigger and more complicated things.

Call random companies (from a secure line) and tell them you are scheduled to come out and inspect the HVAC systems in the server rooms. See how many give you permission and even help walk you into a room with the most sensitive information and most expensive equipment the companies owns. If a single one does- you've just hacked a company by using social engineering. Call their CIO and tell them what their receptionist just offered you- now you are a white hat hacker. Otherwise, throw on some overalls and grab a clip board and take the tour- now you are a black hat hacker. Hacking people is easy- hacking a system requires intimate knowledge of how the system works, its weaknesses, and most importantly how to exploit it.

There is no step by step process. Firstly, you need to know exactly, what you want to do in hacking, I mean, what you want to hack, as everything is independent of anything. Then secondly, you need to learn basics of hacking, try using third party tools, i.e. hacking with softwares, then try to figure out how those softwares work. Trust me, it will help alot. Then, move on to an operating system named as Kali Linux. I am currently using it, and can say that in the field of hacking, it is the best, I literally mean the best operating system ever. It has loads of tools pre-installed, to help you out. For example→ metasploit. Now, if you are used to it, then you must try learning programming languages. Start with C or C++, as they are comparatively easy, then move on to Java. And finally to Python, which is the most advanced, and awesome language, but extremely tough on the other hand. You can find many, many tutorials on the internet. Hope this helped you.

It depends entirely on what your understanding of “hacker” is. It’s really nothing like what you see on TV, for the most part. People don’t just bash randomly on a keyboard for a few mins and say “I’m in!” with a big green “Access Granted” icon flashing on the screen. It also depends on what your level of understanding is right now. Do you know much about, for example, TCP/IP? How firewalls work? How the different operating systems handle security authorisations? There are a myriad of different aspects to computer and network security, so I would start by figuring out what you want to actually accomplish.

The 1st thing you need to learn is everything you can about what it is that you want to hack. Learning programming and reverse engineering is also a must if you ever want to be a good hacker. Other than that, there are tons of freely available tools and tutorials online that will teach you how to hack specific things with specific vulnerabilities. These can help familiarize yourself with various processes, but they also limit you to known vulnerabilities that haven’t been patched. If all you want to do is scan the internet for people that have poor security/update practices this may suffice, but if you want to go after specific targets or do quality penetration testing for customers you really need to learn about software, operating systems, and networking down to the smallest details.
